title.narrative: COVID-19 RBA in SRHR EngenderHealth Ethiopia 2019-2022
COVID-19 RBA inom SRHR EngenderHealth Etiopien 2019-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Den förslagna insatsens syfte är att bidra till rättighetsbaserad samt ökad tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR) services i Etiopien. Detta syfte är högst relevanta i den etiopiska kontexten där det beräknas att över en tredjedel av tonåringar och ungdomar inte har tillgång till sådana tjänster.
Mer specifikt, insatsen syftar till att främja följande rättigheter: -Rätten att själva bestämma om, när och hur många barn man ska ha. -Rätten till SRHR-relaterad information och services. -Rätten att vara fri från könsrelaterat våld.
För att uppnå detta mål kommer unga kvinnors och mäns egenmakt att stärkas som ”rättighetsbärare” för kunna kräva sina SRHR medans service leverantörer och utbildare kommer att stärkas som ”ansvarstagare” för att skapa en möjliggörande miljö för unga människor att utöva sina rättigheter. Insatsens fokus är därför:
-Förbättra kvinnors och flickors förmåga till att utöva sina SRHR. -Förbättra ansvarsutkrävning avseende ansvarstagare och minska diskriminering av kvinnors och flickors tillgång till SRHR-information och service. -Stärka den möjliggörande miljön på interpersonell- och familjenivå för att stödja kvinnor och flickor att kräva och utöva SRHR.
Fokus kommer att omfatta uppföljning och utvärdering och lärande.
Totalt kommer insatsen att nå 7680 flickor och pojkar i Addis Ababa under tre år. Projektet kommer att piloteras i Addis Abeba, med målet att skapa en replikerbar modell för att expandera till andra områden efter piloten. Addis Abeba har valts ut som pilotplats främst på grund av de stora koncentrationerna av unga människor och den ökande migrationsgraden till staden från landsbygden.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The focus of the project is to: -Improve women and girls’ agency to exercise their SRHR in Ethiopia. -Improve duty bearers’ accountability and reduce discrimination towards women and girls’ access to SRH information and services. -Strengthen the enabling environment at interpersonal and family level to support women and girls to demand and exercise SRHR.
In order to achieve this goal, young women and men will be empowered as the “rights holders” to demand their SRHR while service providers and educators will be strengthened as the “duty bearers” to create an enabling environment for young people to exercise these rights.
Focus will also be on monitoring and evaluation and learning.
The project will reach 7,680 girls and boys over three years. The project will be piloted in Addis Ababa, with the aim to create a replicable model to expand into other areas after the pilot. Addis Ababa has been selected as the pilot location primarily for the large concentrations of young people and the increasing rates of migration into the city from rural areas.

The overarching goal of this intervention is that women and girls fulfil their SRHRs. The specific focus of the project will, furthermore, be on the rights that are at the core of the international conference on population and development (ICPD): right to decide, if, when, and how many children to have; right to SRH-related information and services; and, right to be free from violence. In order to achieve this goal, young women and men will be empowered as the ‘rights holders’ to demand their SRHR while service providers and educators will be strengthened as the ‘duty bearers’ to create an enabling environment for young people to exercise these rights. The project stipulates the following objectives: -Improve women and girls’ agency to exercise their SRHR.-Improve duty bearers’ accountability and reduce discrimination towards women and girls’ access to SRH information and services.-Strengthen the enabling environment at interpersonal and family level to support women and girls to demand and exercise SRHRs. There is also an objective dedicated to monitoring and evaluation as well as learning.

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: During 2020, the cooperation partner has, despite Covid-19 related challenges managed to achieve a number of results. These include but are not limited to: - Covid-19 media awareness campaigns that integrated SGBV and SRHR messaging using TV talk shows and radio programmes. These are estimated to have reached approximately 50 million people and 2.5 million people, respectively. - Rapid assessment of weak spots and barriers in SRHR education and the drafting of a curriculum that integrates SRHR and life skills. Based on rapid assessment, using two languages (Amharic and Oromiffa) age-appropriate and educational video spots on SGBV and SRHR were developed and broad casted through one TV station (AfriHealth TV) dedicated for media based education. In addition, the messages were disseminated using social media platforms such as Telegram, Facebook, YouTube and Twitter. Through these intervention, approximately 246,587 young individuals aged between 13-34 were reached. - To improve the knowledge, skills, and attitudes of educators on SRHR integrated with Covid-19 response, the project trained 97 biology teachers (20 females and 77 males), school principals and biology department leads (80 biology teachers, 8 school principals and 8 biology department leads) on adolescent and youth health. This included SRHR, gender-responsive facilitation skills for SRHR topic and transformation manual to enable reflection on harmful norms, biases and prejudices that impede full access to SRHR for young people. - The project collaborated with the Addis Ababa Police Commission to expand helpline services for SGBV response and support. With this intervention, SGBV survivors now have access to support from police officers, psychological counselors and lawyers, and thus can be provided with legal services, counseled, and referred to health facilities. - In addition to the expanded helpline, the project also piloted community-based structures to prevent GBV. This included setting up GBV prevention committees in selected districts in 10 sub-cities and subsequently training 445 committee members, ranging from religious leaders, local police, youth leaders etc. This was done to improve accountability on community level and improve GBV survivor referral systems and data collection for local administrations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
